results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 102nd street and Amsterdam Ave. The entrance gate is located on west101st and Amsterdam ave. 

Directions: 1 train to 103rd St. Also, B or D trains to 103rd St stop

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Planned Route: http://www.ramblr.com/web/mymap/trip/47098/297709/

AMC Trip Listing: http://activities.outdoors.org/search/index.cfm/action/details/id/89166

Here comes the first Catskill 3500 series! Before I knew it, I'm already one-third of the way towards the 35er. So, I decided to bag the rest and get a precious patch and sticker! LOL In this hike, we will bag 3 of the 3500 series, including Wittenberg, Cornell and Slide mountains. To make the hike little more challenging, we will do the reverse route, which is going to give us 3700 feet total elevation gain as opposed to 2600' from the other way around. The average pace of the hike will be 2~2.5 miles/hour, including the breaks in between. In other words, we will maintain 3~3.5 miles/hour pace while in motion for the stretch of 9 miles. I will refrain myself from using descriptive adjectives like fast, brisk, moderate, slow, as we all have different skills and experience level, but I can certainly assure you that it is not suitable for the beginners. Unless someone volunteers to be the sweep, you will have to navigate yourself out, as the leader will not wait for the strugglers more than 10 minutes at the junctions. So study the map, know exactly where you are going and bring a regional trail map and compass, if not a GPS device. Even though it has been the warmest winter with barely any snow, expect some icy patch along the trail, esp. higher up in the altitude. So, don't forget to bring traction devices. As always, better be safe than sorry! The leader will be renting either a 5- or 7-passenger vehicle based on the number of registrants and offer a ride from a central location in Manhattan. All the trip-associated costs will be shared amongst the participants. To secure a spot in the car, you must register via email, FB messenger or Meetup private message by EOD 3/31 (Thurs). The leader will book a car two weeks ahead of the event before the fee skyrockets.
results.name: Young Members - Catskill 3500 Series: Wittenberg/Cornell/Slide Mountains

results.description: Not Suitable for Beginners, slow hikers, runners, and dogs are not allowed.Since last week was wet, and it was unsafe to do the Major Welsh and other rocky trails, and this week it snowed, so let’s hope for dry weather, and do them this Sat. Let’s celebrate Spring by doing a fun hilly demanding 10 mile hike up Bear, West, Timp, and Bald Mountains. We will meet at the Manitou train station at 9:00, and then shuttle over to the parking lot on 9W near the Cornell trail. We will start the hike by hiking up the Cornel trail to the 77 tail, and then take the Major Welch trail up Bear Mountain, and then take the AT down Bear Mountain, and up West. On West Mountain we will then take the TT down West, and up the Timp. We will then take the Rd down the Timp, and up the backside of Bald Mountain. We will then take the C trail back to the cars. The hike will be about 10 miles with four good steep climbs, and will be a fun friendly, but demanding hike with a reasonable number of stops. Leader determines the pace, route, number of stops and duration of stops. If you want to run do not come. If you want to stroll chose another hike. This hike is not easy, and involves 3100 feet of elevation gain. No dogs allowed. Bring at least 3 quarts of water your lunch and wear hiking boots. Rain Cancels. Trans. 5B, but take the Early Metro North Train that leaves 7:48 and arrives at Manitou at 8:58. results.description:
SHAMANIC REIKI I TRAINING


Saturday & Sunday April 16-17, 2016
9:00am-12:30pm & 2:00pm-5:00pm
666 Broadway at Bond
Investment: $275


INSTRUCTOR

Jonathan Hammond is an Energy Healer, Shamanic Practitioner, and Spiritual Counselor in private practice in New York City.

He is a certified Master Teacher in Shamanic Reiki (two year training with Llyn Roberts), and a certified Reiki Master in both Usui and Karuna Reiki from the International Center for Reiki Training.

He has completed all core curriculum through the Foundation For Shamanic Studies, and holds a certification in Cherokee Bodywork.

In addition to his background in energy healing, Jonathan has had four years of training in Inter-Spirituality and Spiritual Counseling at the One Spirit Learning Alliance in New York City, and was ordained as an Interfaith Minister in 2008. He now teaches at One Spirit.


Jonathan is on Llyn Robert’s faculty for her Shamanic Reiki programs and has assisted her at the Omega Institute for the last few years.

He has privately studied Shamanism, meditation, and the chakras with some of the most prominent teachers in North and South America; as well as an apprenticeship with some of the shamans of the Chapada Diamantina in Brazil.

Jonathan runs spiritual retreats around the world. <a>www.livingprojectretreats.com.</a>


He has been a frequent guest on Huffington Post Live speaking about spirituality, energy healing and meditation.


He has a private practice in NYC dedicated to spiritual counseling, shamanic healing, reiki, working with the chakras and breathwork.<a> www.mindbodyspiritnyc.com</a><a href="http://www.mindbodyspiritnyc.com"></a>

results.description:
Register Here: http://www.active.com/woodstock-ny/adventure-racing/races/the-ultimate-ruck-on-the-deadliest-trail-2016


THIS IS AN ADVANCED LEVEL RUCK. You will traverse very dangerous and steep mountains-considered the deadliest trails of the continental US. The intensity of the hike is comparable to an ultra-marathon (8hrs approx.). This is unlike any other hikes we have had and it is specifically designed to challenge the explorers physically and mentally. While you will demonstrate strong leadership skills, you will also have to be able to overcome mental and physical obstacles. The team dynamics is crucial in this expedition. This is not a race, but is a team ruck where you must be willing to push yourself outside your comfort zone and have a "do not quit attitude". Once you complete the 13 mile extremely difficult hike you will earn a one of a kind patch. You will be a stronger and better person. This event will test your limits and bring your fitness to the next level. This hike is for those who are creative and who are independent. You MUST have a car in order to get to the meeting point. We will have a guide and a sweeper to make sure nobody gets lost. Professional photos and T-shirts are also included in the cost. We will move as a unit. Meal and beverage will be provided. You will be cold and wet (you need to pack extra clothes); we will not be camping however you will be required to bring the required gear on the list below. Once you are done with the expedition we will provide you a shuttle back to your car. Again, this is in a wilderness area. There is no public transportation to the meeting spot. No animals are allowed on this hike (it is very steep); You MUST be 18 or older. Once you sign up we will email you specific details (the gear that you need and the meeting place and time). Please read the message carefully before you sign up. Do you have what it takes to tackle the hardest trek in the US? Are you adventurous? Do you like to push your limits? Are you a team player? If YES then this expedition is for you. Each member MUST respect and support one another. We will have less advanced hikes throughout the year. This is our advanced level. We wish you best of luck! See you on the other side of the mountains.

The Lost Tribe Expeditions www.LostTribeExpeditions.com

Event details and schedule


Gear List:

Ruck

Water (2L or more)

Headlamp

Sturdy shoes (preferable hiking boots water/winter proof)

Cold weather hiking clothes +spare (waterproof/winter proof)

Hiking poles (optional)

*there may be ice and snow on these mountains please email us if you need suggestions or help preparing gear above [masked]
results.name: Ultimate Ruck on the Deadliest Trail

results.description:
There are plenty of ups and downs on this hike, making it strenuous.

 Delaware Water Gap Length: 10.5 miles Difficulty: Strenuous Meet-up location: Dunnfield Creek upper parking area, just before the Delaware River bridge Site: Worthington State Forest contains three of New Jersey’s scenic wonders; Mt. Tammany, Sunfish Pond and Dunnfield Creek. The 1,547-foot Mt. Tammany towers 1,200 feet above the Delaware River, offering some of the best scenic views in the state. Sunfish Pond is a glacial pond set atop of the Kittatinny Ridge; its crystal waters and serene setting entice visitors to return. Make sure to check out the various rock structures that inspired hikers have left to honor the beauty of the area. Dunnfield Creek’s pristine, cascading waters, set off by towering hemlocks and mixed hardwood trees, is an experience not to miss. Opportunities for viewing wildlife abound along the various trails that crisscross this area. Details: The hike will start at the base of the Delaware Water Gap and ascend to the top of Mt. Tammany. This is a steep climb and probably the most strenuous part of the hike where the hike gains about 1200ft in elevation. From Mt. Tammany The RED DOT trail ends at the summit. Left on Blue down Mt. Tammany the right on Green to down to Sunfish Pond. We take the AT back to the parking lot.

Gear:

Solid hiking boots (waterproof)

Plenty of water

Lunch for the break at Sunfish pond and snacks to have while moving.

Rain gear as always

Directions:

Parking: N[masked] W[masked]

Route 80 west to just before the last exit in New Jersey. On the right there is a sign for Dunnfield Creek Natural Area. There is a parking lot on the right, then a large main lot in the center and if both are full, you can park on the grass just past the main lot. [directions from nps.gov here]. The road is one way so you can't backtrack to a passed lot unless you get back onto Rt 80 and come around

results.description:
Let’s hike across the Mohonk Mountain House grounds (gorgeous) to the Labyrinth rock scramble and up through the Lemon Squeeze! This hike is one of the most memorable outdoor experiences in the Hudson Valley, or anywhere else. As a reward for wedging yourself through rock formations and volunteering to be a human lemon in the Lemon Squeeze, you’ll pop out onto a ledge with awesome views of the Mohonk Preserve and beyond. Then you can turn around and find the Sky Top Tower right behind you, begging to be climbed. From up there, you can pretty much see the whole world. It’s an amazing experience and truly my favorite in the Hudson Valley region and possibly the state!
Entrance onto the grounds is $26pp but I promise you it is well worth it! After the hike we'll head to downtown New Paltz to hit up one of their lively pubs for a bite to eat and some libations. Car pooling would be great too so we will figure that all out as the event nears.
results.name: Shake off those winter blues with a hike & a drink!

venue.name: Stanley Isaacs Senior Center

results.description:
This volunteer opportunity helps a segment of the NYC population that is particularly vulnerable (our home-bound seniors) and is facing a steadily growing problem - hunger. As our city’s elderly grow older, they are more likely to have mobility limitations, while living at or below the poverty level. The elderly of East Harlem are particularly more vulnerable, residing in challenging living conditions alone, and who can no longer shop or cook for themselves.

Citymeals-on-Wheels (www.citymeals.org) raises private funds to ensure no homebound elderly New Yorker will ever go a day without food or human company. Citymeals funds 33 community-based agencies that bring weekend, holiday and emergency meals to homebound elderly New Yorkers - one of the agencies we'll be helping as volunteers.

How are we helping?

On Saturday, April 16th, we'll assist the Stanley Isaacs Senior Center Citymeals-on-Wheels program with delivery of meals to the elderly. Volunteers should wear weather appropriate clothes and comfortable shoes as deliveries are done on foot within walking distance from the meal center.  Although the weather may not always be favorable, the meals MUST be delivered as many, if not all, of the elderly in the program RELY on the meal delivery for the day.

Our Meetup

We'll meet at the Senior Center at 9:30am on Saturday for a short training, then break into small teams of 3 to 4 people to deliver the meals to the elderly. A light breakfast of juice, coffee, pastry and/or bagels will be offered.

If you RSVP, please try to be on time, or arrive no later than 9:30am, which is when we start delivery. The time commitment ends at 12pm and goes by very quickly.

Afterwards, we'll have brunch at The District - 1679 Third Avenue, on the corner of 94th Street, when everyone is done with their deliveries around 12:30pm.

If you have any questions, running late, need more information on parking and etc., feel free to call/text Daniel at 774.275.3646.

Directions to the Union Settlement Senior Center

The Stanley Isaacs Senior Center is located at 415 East 93rd Street. The closest subway is the #6 train to 96th Street & Lexington Avenue, then walking east to 93rd street & 1st Avenue. The building is offset from the street (toward the FDR Drive), enter through sliding glass doors. The M15 bus line stops nearby, along 1st Avenue (uptown) or 2nd Avenue (downtown).

Thanks and see you there!

results.description:
In this adventure we will be exploring a very seldom visited section of this park (although it may be frequented by locals - we will find out), a strange section, along with a seemingly out of place lean too and a mysterious gated parking area along the Taconic Parkway that is never open and parking by permit only. Whatever is here we have to know. Whatever the case one thing is for sure, Adventure awaits....

The hike is about 1000 vertical feet gain and loss over[masked] miles or so and I will adjust the route as needed to favor a 4 pm end time (Shuttle cars recovered time, not out of the woods time) with hitting as much of this seldom travelled route as possible. Expect easier, east of the Hudson River AT style hiking, we might take a short section of the AT on the return.

Please use this for directions

https://goo.gl/maps/7e8MzVWCvPG2


Additional note: Roshi and I have a event this evening, due to this I will not be hosting after hike festivities on this hike.

Children/teens Welcome: Always (if they are capable, if event is appropriate). Children, including underage teenagers, should be RSVP'ed as a guest their parent, guardian or responsible adult; drop me a message and I will put your child (or underage teenager) in as your guest if guest function is disabled. This does not mean that this is a children's level hike, or if it's a activity that it child appropriate - it is not unless stated so above, but some children are more then able to do a adult level hike and attend events that are not normally well suited for many children such as meditative events.

Guests: Adults need to sign up directly and may not go as guests. Guest function, if enabled for this hike, is only for children (and teens who have not reached the age of majority).

No Shows/ short notice canceling/waitlisted/ not helping out such as with car shuttles: Known 'No shows' may be waitlisted, and / or excluded from the event if there is a max number of hikers set. Repeat short notice canceling will also be noted for consideration for this as well as things like bypassing the car shuttle location. No-showing / short notice canceling prevents others from attending if the event is full. Bypassing the car shuttle start location is taking advantage of others (also see 'Arriving Late: Don't do that' section). Make sure you sign in, you would not want to be accidentally marked as a no-show, additionally frequently a spots are reserved for those who are known to attend and be on time.

Arriving Late: Don't do that, you may be on your own. If you are late, we can only wait if it would be advantageous for the group to wait, so don't be late. We will try to get you back on track, but those mornings are very hectic and my first responsibility would need to be to those hikers that have arrived. You may not get to hike with us, additionally we may not have room to get you back to your vehicle at the end if that is required.

End of Hike Time: Ignore the Meetup end time, that is my suggestion for every meetup you attend, not just mine, that is unless you know the event host uses that. The reason is that Meetup assumes a end time and if the event organizer does not change it it just gives out a standard one. Hikes normally move at 2mph, bushwack sections and scrambles at 1 to 1.5 mph, and any car shuttle set up time if needed for this event. so if the millage is specified one can easily figure out a rough estimate. Larger groups sometimes move slower.

Dogs: I request No Dogs

Recommended Smartphone apps to assist meeting up:

Glympse: Easy to send my location if you get dislocated, by having this app installed you can also add yourself which allows me to note your location and give advice of how to rejoin the group.

Waze: For getting to the meetup location, it allows the good will of others to assist your drive (GPS app with warnings from other users).

The use of Apple Maps have proven itself unreliable and I can not recommend it.

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
Rockaway Beach Spring Ride!
Saturday, April 16th - Rockaway Beach Spring Ride!
Meeting @: Prospect Park ( Parkside & Ocean Aves.)
Time: 9:45
Distance: 20 miles all flat.
Pace: Easy flowing group pace.
Fee: $10 Guidance & Support.
**Additional starting point for Manhattan crew**
Brooklyn Bridge/Borough Pk@ 9:am, must have 4 or more people, otherwise Prospect Pk it is.

This is the urban ride to start your spring. There'll be tree lined streets out to the bay and a easy rolling pace to the Atlantic. The route is scenic, steady going, light traffic and 90% bike lanes/bike paths. We'll stop by one of the local Rockaway deli's for sandwiches to eat out on the boardwalk before heading back. A nice short and sweet ride to began your biking season.

PLEASE BRING BOTH A BLUE T-SHIRT & A WHITE T-SHIRT.                                                                                                                                                                                 Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown: 

1. Play safe,  excessive aggression will NOT be tolerated (the precinct is across the street...LOL!!). 

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St. with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street.

Time: 9:45
Distance: 20 miles all flat.
Pace: Easy flowing group pace.
Fee: $10 Guidance & Support.
**Additional starting point for Manhattan crew**
Brooklyn Bridge/Borough Pk. Manhattan @9:am, must have 4 or more people (RSVP for this starting point please) otherwise Prospect Pk it is.

This is the urban ride to start your spring. There'll be tree lined streets out to the bay and a easy rolling pace to the Atlantic. The route is scenic, steady going, light traffic and 90% bike lanes/bike paths. We'll stop by one of the local Rockaway deli's for sandwiches to eat out on the boardwalk before heading back. A nice short and sweet ride to began your biking season.

results.description: Sat., Apr. 16. Bronx Botanical Garden. Should be a perfect day to visit the Garden. Daffodils, magnolias, cherries, lilacs, crab apples, and tulips should all be in bloom. Then we'll walk through NYC's only primeval forest. After lunch, those who wish can visit the orchid show in the conservatory (admission fee). Around 3 miles at a very leisurely pace. Take the 9:25 Harlem Line train from Grand Central, arriving at the "Botanical Garden" Station at 9:44. Get "City Ticket" $4. Alternatively, take the 4 or D subway to "Bedford Park Blvd." and then the #26 bus east to the Mosholu Gate entrance -- or, the 2 subway to "Allerton Ave." and then the #26 bus west to the entrance. Meet just inside the Mosholu Gate at 9:45. Admission to the Garden is free until 10am on Saturdays. If driving, park in the parking facility by the station ($12) or on a nearby street (free). No coordination of rides. The 3:37 train gets you back to Grand Central at 3:59, or you can take the bus and subway back. Bring lunch and beverage, or buy it in the cafeteria. No pets; no smoking. Please email or call me to make sure that the visit is on, to let me know you are coming, or if you have any questions. Bob Susser[masked]; [masked]

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Here is a typical agenda of Art of Speaking Toastmasters Club's meeting.


• The Sgt at Arms calls for meeting to begin

• President of the club welcomes members and guests.  Invites the Toastmaster of the day to facilitate the meeting

• Toastmaster of the Day (TMOD) introduces other duty holders.


• TMOD invites speakers who have scheduled to speak that day. Members take turns to complete their projects under the Competent Communication manual or from one of the advanced manuals. Members & Guests offer feedback to the speakers. They also fill out ballots to select best speaker.


• After the prepared speeches segment is complete, Impromptu speeches (Table Topics) segment begins. All Guests are invited to participate. The goal is to think on your feet and speak for 1 to 2 minutes. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best Table Topics contestant.


• Short Break to enable socializing & networking.


• Meeting reconvenes. General Evaluator takes charge of the meeting. Invites Evaluators to present their feedback on the prepared speeches. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best evaluator.


• General Evaluators returns the control of the meeting back to the President of the club.


• President gives away awards to the best speaker, best Table Topics contestant and best Evaluator.


• Meeting comes to an end approximately between 12.15 pm and 12.30 pm.
results.how_to_find_us: North Edison Public Library
results.name: Art of Speaking Toastmasters Club Meeting

The Institute for Architectural Research, Inc. is offering a two-part workshop on the art and geometry of interior sketching. The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen (20 West 44th Street) will be our lab in which we will learn the basics of interior perspective, orthographic projection, and line weights. The course is open to all levels of drawing experience.

Session 2 (April 16): basic on drawing interior perspectives


There is no requirement for sketchbooks, or pencils; please be prepared with your own material. However, if you would like to buy a sketchbook, the Institute for Architectural Research offers a sketching kit, which includes a unique Institute & ASID sketchbook; pencils, erasers, and sketch & wash pencil. Kits will be hand delivered at the start of the workshop.

results.description:
The Bear Mountain Loop is a fantastic hike with beautiful views and challenging inclines. A demanding all-day loop rolls through steep wooded terrain, topping Bear and West Mountains, offering views of the lower Hudson River area. Special Attractions: vistas, Perkins Tower, lean-to, historic area, Mountain laurel and dogwood blooms. The shelter at West Mountain has amazing views over the Hudson and of Manhattan in the distance. We'll take an extended lunch break at this shelter. Afterwards, we'll get drinks and dinner nearby.

NOTE: We'll be hiking this at an intermediate pace, with plenty of breaks for rest and pictures. The hike should take approximately 6 hours.

Disclaimer:

Participation in activities is strictly voluntary and group members assume all risks in connection with activities; per Meetup.com's Terms of Service Agreements, organizers and hike/trip leaders are released from any and all forms of liability related to events.

results.description:
COME JOIN US FOR SOME WILD CREVICE EXPLORATION IN THE SHAWANGUNKS! 

Though I've previously explored these spots there will be some route finding to get to and from the crevices so attendees should be prepared for whatever the day may bring.  Some of these crevices will be "cave-like" in nature.  Headlamps are mandatory!

On this trip you can expect to encounter "Cave-like" Crevices.  You should have good balance and be prepared for a full body workout.  I will bring some webbing to use as a hand line to assist in some more difficult to negotiate areas.

WHERE TO MEET?

WE WILL START AT THE UPPER PARKING AREA ADJACENT TO LAKE MINNEWASKA ALL THE WAY UP THE HILL AFTER PASSING THROUGH THE MAIN ENTRANCE GATE.

Distance: approx 8 miles

Hiking Pace: Slow but physically challenging

Estimated Hike Time: 6-7 hours

Difficulty: Intermediate - Rocky (possibly Slippery) Terrain and Crevices with possible exposures - I will bring a 50 ft. hand-line to help navigate any hard terrain.

Current Weather Forecast: Mostly Sunny with a high of 67 Degrees

Fee: $10. per car


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip and ankle support


• Headlamp with spare batteries - preferably 100 lumens or brighter and hands-free


• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.


RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set


AFTER THE HIKE FEEL FREE TO JOIN US FOR SOME FOOD AND DRINKS AT THE

MAIN COURSE MARKETPLACE

175 Main Street
New Paltz, NY 12561

Relax from the past week, breath in the fresh air, listen to the birds sing and spot what nature has to offer in Brooklyns gorgeous haven. We will meet at the West Drive entrance (cross streets are Garfield place and Prospect park west) and make our way around the beautiful lake, past Breeze Hill and Neathermead back to West Drive and stop off for a coffee and snack. Perfect for a relaxing early morning walk with or without a dog. As BornWild is aimed at giving a major portion of its profits to Charity, donations are welcome although not essential.
results.name: Beautiful Prospect Park Dog Walk and Cafe! (with or without a dog)

results.description: Warm at last! Bring iPod & earbuds--everybody listens to their own music as we dance walk around the park loop. What is "Dance Walking"? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. Check out this funny and smart article published about the Dance Walk in Prospect Park: http://themomtropolis.com/dance-walk-you-know-you-want-to/
results.how_to_find_us: Standing in Grand Army Plaza farmer's market, walk 50 paces up toward the park on the park drive. We meet on the grassy triangle, just shy of the park loop.

results.description:
LEADER: Despina Metaxatos ([masked] or[masked]) 

RATING: B 5/6 B

Meet at 10 AM at Stonetown Recreation Area (Mary Roth Drive) off Stonetown Rd. in Ringwood, NJ. Take Stonetown Circular Trail to Tory Rocks and back along woods roads to explore interesting rock formations, including Signal Rock. Some climbing and potential bushwacking. TC North Jersey Trails map 115. 

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance: Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.
results.name: Stonetown Rocks

Catskills Beginner - Kaaterskill Falls & Southern Escarpment Trail

Saturday, April 9, 2016

Distance: 5.5 miles

Total Elevation Gain: 800'

Pace/Time:  about 1.5 MPH - 5-6 hours with breaks for rest & views


Getting there: Take the New York State Thruway to exit 20: Saugerties. Turn left and then keep right to go onto Rt. 32 north.  Bear left onto Rt. 32A at Palenville (Big Belly Deli on left).  At traffic light turn left onto Rt. 23A and ascend mountain road.  In Haines Falls, turn right onto North Lake Rd..  Laurel House Rd. will be on the right - parking area is at end of road.  Be early -- Start 10 a.m. SHARP!!   Rain will cancel hike!!
  
Route Description: We will first go around 1/4 mile down the Kaaterskill Rail Trail (KRT), to get the best view of Kaaterskill Falls, on a currently unmarked path.  Then back track and take the trail to the new viewing platform for the falls.  After the view, we will follow a path and find the area with the best stepping stones to cross the stream above the falls, to get to the Escarpment Trail.  There are fantastic views of the Kaaterskill Clove, including Layman Monument, Sunset Rock, and Inspiration Point.  The ES trail will intersect with an old carriage road (now horse trail), which we will take to reach the ES trail a short distance above where we entered it.  Then it's back across the stream and up to the parking area.

Attendance Request:  This hike is intended to introduce beginners to Catskills hiking.  All are requested to remain with the group, not go racing ahead and possibly go the wrong way. 

Special Gear / Requirements: Sturdy hiking boots/shoes, with good gripping tread - NO FLIP-FLOPS!!!  Warm and cool weather wicking clothing (avoid cotton!), food/water as you feel is appropriate, first aid, insulating layer and rain gear (just in case), trail conference map #141.  Hiking poles can be of great assistance & give some upper body workout.

Kaaterskill Falls from KRT view point (under construction).  Best view possible of both tiers of the falls.  Total drop is more than Niagara Falls!!! 


  
Group Size: The DEC limits group sizes in the Kaaterskill Wild Forest to 20.

---

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.  Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
On May 20th we're organizing an FPV race competition to be held on Pier A in Hoboken at the 2016 annual Propeller Festival - It will be close to the main stage with a 80'x40' netted area _ Engraved Trophy for the overall winner


It will be a part of this day long Music meets Tech event, which culminates in an evening of music under the stars and is the first of several similar qualifying events for a regular series which will grow into a full scale annual Grand Prix of NJ venues.

   Today is first of 3 time trials to Qualify for that competition.

When you arrive, you may drive in the gate shown below and carry your gear through to the second field leaving it with our security for safe keeping.

Then return to your car, drive out the gate you came in, down the hill and turn right into the 2nd parking lot on your right.

Walk across the bridge and follow the colored cords up to the first field and back to your gear in the second field... 


...DOWNLOAD this map chart



TIME TRIAL:

1  Practice Run before you start
2 Attempts (your fastest time is used)
3 Laps of the course


10:45   Pilot's briefing (if you miss it, you'll race last)
11:30    Walk the course
12:00   Time Trials start


RULES:  To qualify for the main races, you must be an experienced FPV racer in one of the two classes (3s under 230mm or 4s under 250mm) and show proof of liability insurance coverage (AMA membership, homeowners etc.).
•  If less than 3 entries in a class, that class will be postponed until a future Qualifying.
•  Any UAV over .55lbs must be FAA registered and labeled.
•  You will then compete in one of our Qualifying events for the top 10 spots with a engraved Trophy for the overall winner


The fee to compete will be $25 ($10 admin and $15 refundable if you crash out) payable at the gate.

We need Marshals, Timekeepers and Judges. _ Spectators are welcome.

Once the Qualifying is concluded, we will continue the meeting (time allowing) as a regular Fly-In _ so don't forget to bring your non-racing birds to fly too.

(details are subject to change)
results.name: FPV Qualifying for the Propeller Quad Races
